The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Natural Catastrophe Risk Management and Insurance Act of 2007" and includes sections on findings, establishment, membership, duties, report, powers, personnel matters, termination, and authorization of appropriations. Congress finds that Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, and Wilma in 2005 caused over $200 billion in economic losses, with predictions of increased hurricane activity. Billions have been provided for natural catastrophe losses, leading to challenges in obtaining affordable insurance coverage as insurers are limiting policies and raising rates. The increasing rates and deductibles in some markets, along with the inability of property and business owners in vulnerable areas to obtain affordable insurance coverage, pose a threat to the national economy and public health. Almost every state in the US is at risk of natural catastrophes, and building codes and land use regulations are crucial in managing these risks. Several proposals in Congress aim to address the affordability and availability of natural disaster insurance. The Federal Government's role in addressing the affordability and availability of natural catastrophe insurance in the US is debated. A proposal suggests establishing a nonpartisan commission to study natural catastrophe risk management and insurance. A nonpartisan Commission on Natural Catastrophe Risk Management and Insurance is established. The Commission on Natural Catastrophe Risk Management and Insurance consists of 16 members appointed by various leaders from the Senate and House of Representatives. The Commission on Natural Catastrophe Risk Management and Insurance consists of 16 members appointed by leaders from the Senate and House of Representatives. Members must have expertise in various fields such as insurance, reinsurance, policyholder concerns, risk management, financial markets, flood mapping, structural engineering, and environmental issues. Members must have expertise in various fields such as insurance, reinsurance, policyholder concerns, risk management, financial markets, flood mapping, structural engineering, and environmental issues. The appointments to the Commission aim for diversity and representation of various perspectives within the United States. Each member is appointed for the duration of the Commission, and vacancies are to be filled promptly. The Commission on Natural Catastrophe Risk Management and Insurance consists of 16 members appointed by leaders from the Senate and House of Representatives. Vacancies on the Commission will not affect its powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings and approval actions require a majority vote. The Commission will select a Chairperson by majority vote and meetings will be held at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members. The Commission on Natural Catastrophe Risk Management and Insurance has duties outlined in Section 5. The Commission examines risks posed by natural catastrophes in the US, assesses insurance market conditions post major hurricanes, evaluates availability and affordability of insurance nationwide, reviews mitigation efforts by States and individuals, and analyzes ongoing exposure to natural disasters like hurricanes, earthquakes, and volcanic eruptions. The curr_chunk discusses catastrophic insurance and reinsurance markets, the implementation of a catastrophic insurance system, and the financial feasibility of a national pooling mechanism to increase insurance capacity. The curr_chunk focuses on partnerships to increase insurance capacity in constrained markets, promoting public insurance policies to reduce losses from natural catastrophes in uninsured sectors, implementing insurance schemes for low-income communities, and analyzing the impact of Federal and State laws on catastrophe insurance affordability and availability. The curr_chunk discusses the capacity of the private insurance market to cover losses from natural catastrophes, the development of high-risk areas, and the costs of natural disasters to taxpayers. It also addresses the financial condition of State residual markets and catastrophe funds in high-risk regions, the role of innovation in financial services in improving natural catastrophe insurance affordability and availability. The curr_chunk focuses on promoting the development of financial products for natural catastrophe insurance, strengthening land use regulations and building codes in high-risk areas, and evaluating the benefits and costs of proposed Federal natural catastrophe insurance programs. The curr_chunk discusses the ability of the private insurance market to cover insured losses from natural catastrophes, including the impact of demographic trends on future losses. The curr_chunk addresses the role of the Federal Government in stabilizing property and casualty insurance markets and providing incentives for risk mitigation efforts at the federal, state, and local levels. SEC. 6. REPORT.

The Commission will submit a final report on December 1, 2008, to the Senate and House committees containing findings, assessments, and recommendations for actions at various levels. The Commission has the authority to hold meetings, hearings, and obtain official data from government agencies to carry out the purposes of the Act. Members can attend meetings and vote in person, via telephone conference, or via video conference. Any member or agent of the Commission can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission has the authority to request information from government agencies, use postal services, receive administrative support services, and accept gifts to aid its work under this Act. The Commission may accept volunteer services without compensation and reimburse for travel and office supplies. It can also enter into contracts with various entities for necessary activities. The Commission may enter into contracts for necessary activities, but these contracts cannot extend beyond the Commission's termination date. SEC. 8. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Commission members are allowed travel expenses and per diem for subsistence. The Commission can establish subcommittees and appoint members accordingly. The Chairperson can appoint additional personnel as needed. Staff of the Commission may be subject to certain civil service laws. The Commission staff can be appointed without following certain civil service laws and paid without adhering to specific pay rate regulations. The Commission can also hire consultants and experts at rates not exceeding those of a GS-15 employee. Upon request, Federal Government employees may be detailed to the Commission to assist without interruption or loss of civil service status or privilege. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. Appropriations are authorized for the Commission to carry out its duties.
